They could not deepen the impression and renew

the scarcity of Elizabethan criticism; and the general nature
of what criticism there is. Both Sidney and Jonson

deal with the general rules of poetry; not with the

The sound of the spoken word We have lost the sound of the
spoken word; all that the sight of the actors bodies
suggests to the mind through the eye. We have lost the

sense of being part of the audience. We miss a

                  thousand
suggestions that the dramatist conveyed by the inflection
of voice, by gesture, by the placing of the actors bodies.
This can still be proved by comparing our impression

aft

still something in every Elizabethan play sunk beyond recall.
Presumably the earlier plays, in which the playwright
and the audience were more in closer cooperation, are the

more damaged by reading them. The reader

old scattered bones. At some point however in Elizabethan

of the play as a work of art; when he is able to unite the

We can be sure then that the reader has been
in existence for round about four hundred years. But his
life history is an obscure one. At some point his ear must

have lost

Elizabethan spelling brings in suggestions that give it
almost another meaning. The words suggest other manners,
